name: Accounting Principles
description: Introduction to basic accounting principles and practices. Emphasis is placed on the accounting cycle and the key financial statements necessary for business decisions. Introduces basic financial and managerial accounting concepts.

notes: Not available for credit towards the Bachelor of Commerce degree. Preference in enrolment is given to students who have declared a Management and Society Minor. Will not act as a prerequisite for any higher level accounting course.

name: Introductory Managerial Acct
description: An introduction to the use of accounting within an organizational context. Emphasis is placed on the development and dissemination of accounting information necessary for effective management including: planning, directing, motivating, and controlling activities and behaviours.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and Accounting 217.
antireq: Credit for Accounting 323 and 301 will not be allowed.

name: Intermediate Financial Acct I
description: Financial accounting from a producer point of view. Topics include cash, receivables, inventories, short and long-term investments, intangible assets and capital assets including the appropriate financial statement considerations.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 217 and 323.

rules.name: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

name: Intermediate Financial Acct II
description: Financial accounting from a producer point of view. Topics include accounting for liabilities, shareholders equity, leases, future income taxes, pensions, accounting changes and earnings per share including the relevant financial statement considerations.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Accounting 341.

rules.name: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business.

name: IntroductoryFinancialAccountin
description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations. Reporting of financial results of operations and financial position to investors, managers, and others. Emphasis on the use of accounting information for decision-making.

name: Financial Accounting Concepts
description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations emphasizing the preparation and use of financial statements for decision-making purposes.
prereq: Admission to the Master of Management program.

name: Management Accounting
description: Break even analysis, activity-based costing and management, budgeting, productivity measures, and other tools and techniques that are part of a planning and control system that will help the manager make better economic decisions.

name: Managerial Accounting Concepts
description: Introduction to the use of accounting within an organizational context. Emphasis is placed on the development and dissemination of accounting information necessary for effective management.
prereq: Admission to the Master of Management program.

name: Taxation
description: Discusses the core concepts, regulations, and interpretations underlying the Canadian individual and corporate income taxation. Emphasis is on who is taxable, on what income, when and how tax is calculated. Tax planning opportunities will be identified by using long-term and clientele-based techniques.

name: Advanced Taxation I
description: Focuses on tax planning. It extends the material covered in the introductory tax course with an examination of specialized topics in personal and corporate income tax.

name: Intermediate Fnce ACCT I
description: Provides detailed coverage of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) primarily related to assets. Emphasizes the theory behind the methods, the strengths and weaknesses of such methods and the need for sound professional judgement.
prereq: Accounting 601 and 603; or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

name: Financial Statement Analysis
description: Covers the theories, concepts and practices of financial statement analysis with an emphasis placed on applications.

name: Intermediate Fnce ACCT II
description: Builds on Intermediate Financial Accounting I with coverage of the Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) primarily related to liabilities and owners' equity. Emphasizes the theory behind the methods, the strengths and weaknesses of methods and the need for sound professional judgment.

name: Advanced Financial Accounting
description: Focuses on advanced accounting methods related to inter-corporate investments and financial reporting. Topics include accounting for business combinations and inter-corporate investments, foreign currency transactions and translation, bankruptcy, partnerships, and not-for-profit organizations.

name: Accounting Theory
description: Examines the conceptual framework underlying the preparation of financial accounting information, and the theories and propositions on the use of such information by investors, regulators, standard setters, and other corporate stakeholders.

name: Integrative Accounting I
description: Integrated application of the technical CPA competencies relating to financial reporting, audit, finance, taxation, and performance management within case scenarios that provide a rich professional context.
prereq: Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 443 or 644.

name: Advanced Taxation II
description: Further development of taxation competency by focusing on tax compliance and planning issues for individuals, corporations, trusts and partnerships within case scenarios, which focus on tax implications of business decisions.
prereq: Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 423 or 623.

name: Cost Accounting
description: Provides intermediate level discussions to the production and analysis of costs used for pricing, production and investment decisions, revenue analysis, performance evaluation, management incentive systems and strategy analysis.

name: Managerial Control Systems
description: Emphasis is placed on how managers use planning and control to accomplish a firm's strategies. Uses a case approach to management control systems explaining the usefulness of accounting data from a managerial perspective.

name: Auditing
description: Discusses the techniques and theory behind the external auditor's provision of assurance services on financial information. Topics include: the demand for assurance, the role of auditors in providing assurance, auditor independence, audit reports, and audit liability.

name: Advanced Auditing
description: Further development of assurance competencies necessary to perform internal audit projects and external assurance engagements, including assessing needs, developing and performing procedures, and documenting and reporting results for realistic case scenarios.
prereq: Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 425 or 666.

name: Integrative Accounting II
description: Integrated application of the CPA competencies of strategy, governance in management accounting within case scenarios that demonstrate how to build control systems and perform financial analysis for different entities.
prereq: Admission to Master of Business Administration and Accounting 465 or 665.

name: Seminar in Accounting
description: Development of and solutions to current issues and problems in accounting.
prereq: Accounting 603 or consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

name: Financial Accounting Concepts
description: Introduction to accounting for business organizations emphasizing the use and analysis of financial statements for decision-making purposes.
prereq: Admission to the Master of Management (MMgmt) Program.

name: Managerial Accounting Concepts
description: Introduction to the use of accounting within an organizational context. Emphasis is placed on the development and dissemination of accounting information necessary for effective management.
prereq: Admission to the Master of Management (MMgmt) Program.

prereq: Consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

name: TheoryOfInterest/MathOfFnce
description: Measurement of interest, elementary annuities, general annuities, amortization schedules and sinking funds, bonds and other securities.

name: Life Contingencies I
description: The survival function, force of mortality, life tables, analytical laws of mortality, life insurance, continuous and discrete life annuities, recursion equations. Introduction to benefit premiums and/or insurance and annuity models with interest as a random variable as time permits.

name: Intermediate FNCE & Investment
description: Mean-variance portfolio theory, asset pricing models, market efficiency and behavioral finance, investment risk and project analysis, capital structure.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 425 and Finance 317 will be not be allowed without consent of the Department.

name: Life Contingencies II
description: Benefit premiums, premium principles, fully continuous and fully discrete premiums. Benefit reserves and their analysis. Insurance models including expenses. Multiple-state models.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 313, 367 or 375.

name: Actuarial Models
description: Basic distributional quantities; characteristics of actuarial models; continuous models; Basic and advanced discrete distributions; frequency and severity with coverage modifications (deductibles, policy limits, coinsurance); aggregate loss models.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 437 and Statistics 437 will not be allowed.

name: Genr'l Linear Models Actuaries
description: Description of insurance data, response distributions, exponential family responses and estimation, GLMs, models for count data, categorical and continuous responses. Applications include: personal injury insurance, vehicle insurance, diabetes deaths, third party claims, and degree of vehicle crash. Software for fitting GLMs will be discussed.

name: Fundamentals Actuarial Pract
description: An introduction to the foundations of actuarial science including the history and development of insurance, the actuarial profession, and the professional societies. Standards of practice and codes of ethics and conduct. An examination of the contexts and environments (including the legal, political, and societal) in which actuarial work takes place. Foundational skills required by actuaries, with an emphasis on communication.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 513 and 539.02 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 513 and 539.02 will not be allowed.

name: Models for Financial Economics
description: Survey of financial derivatives, valuation of derivatives using binomial trees, Black-Scholes-Merton equation, dynamic hedging, Brownian motion and Ito's Lemma.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 515 and 539.04 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 515 and 539.04 will not be allowed.

name: Estmt'ng Unpaid Claims Gen Ins
long_name: Estimating Unpaid Claims in General Insurance
description: Data collection, adjusting premiums, trending losses, development triangles, expected method, frequency-severity method, Bornhuetter Ferguson method, Benktander method, Cape Cod method, impact of changing conditions on projection method.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 517 and 539.06 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 517 and 539.06  (Interest Rate Modelling) will not be allowed.

name: Quantitative Fnc'l Risk Mgmt
description: Risk measures, correlations and copulas, various approaches to modeling market and credit risk, liquidity risk, enterprise risk management.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 519 and 539.01 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 519 and 539.01 will not be allowed.

name: Mathematics of Graduation
description: Preparation and testing of graduations of mortality tables; graduation by the moving-weighted average, graphic, Whittaker, Bayesian, parametric and smooth-junction interpolation methods; use of statistical methods for graduation.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327 and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323; or consent of the Department.

name: Life Contingencies III
description: Multiple life functions, dependent and independent models, related annuities and insurances. Multiple decrement models: time until and causes of death. Associated single decrement tables. Applications of multiple decrement theory. Asset shares. Business and regulatory considerations.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; 3 units from Mathematics 311, 313, 367 or 375; and 3 units from Computer Science 217, 231, 235 or Data Science 211.

name: Loss Distributions&Estimations
description: Review of mathematical statistics; estimation based on complete and modified data; frequentist estimation; Bayesian estimation; simulation in actuarial modelling; model selection.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 313, 367 or 375.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 531 and 533 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 531 and 533 will not be allowed.

name: Credibility Theory & Loss Dist
description: Distributions useful for modelling insurance loss random variables. Approximations for and estimation of these loss distributions. Point and interval estimation, and tests of statistical hypotheses. Introduction to credibility theory, experience rating and claims reserving. Bayesian inferential techniques. Stochastic simulation and computational techniques.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; and Mathematics 323 or Statistics 323.
notes: Statistics 437 is strongly recommended as preparation for this course.

name: Mathematics of Demography
description: Conventional and adjusted measures of mortality; measures of fertility; measures of morbidity; North American demographic characteristics and trends; evaluation of demographic data; projections for stable and stationary populations; actuarial applications of demographic characteristics and trends.

name: Credibility Theory
description: Limited fluctuation credibility; full and partial credibility; greatest accuracy credibility; Bayesian methodology; credibility premium; Buhlmann model; Buhlmann-Straub model; empirical Bayes method; bonus-malus system.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 313, 367 or 375.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 537 and either 533 or 637 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Actuarial Science 537 and either 533 or 637 will not be allowed.

name: Special Topics in ACSC
description: Study in advanced topics that may include reading projects, seminars, lectures, term papers and other aspects of training in theory or research methodology.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323; and 3 units from Mathematics 311, 313, 367 or 375.

name: Research Seminar
description: A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential for students to succeed in their future careers. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern actuarial techniques and statistical research tools. Ethics and professionalism are also covered.

name: Research Seminar
description: A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential for students to succeed in their future careers. The emphasis is on delivering professional presentations and using modern actuarial techniques and statistical research tools. Ethics and professionalism are also covered.

name: Research Seminar
description: A professional skills course, focusing on the development of technical proficiencies that are essential for students to succeed in their future careers. description: Description of insurance data, response distributions, exponential family responses and estimation, GLMs, models for count data, categorical and continuous responses. Applications include: personal injury insurance, vehicle insurance, diabetes deaths, third party claims, and degree of vehicle crash. Software for fitting GLMs will be discussed.

long_name: Estimating Unpaid Claims in General Insurance

antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 617 and either 517 or 539.06 will not be allowed.

name: Quantitative Fnc'l Risk Mgm't
description: Risk measures, correlations and copulas, various approaches to modelling market and credit risk, liquidity risk, enterprise risk management.

name: Advanced Life Contingencies
description: Multiple life functions, dependent and independent models, related annuities and insurances. Multiple decrement models: time until and causes of death. Associated single decrement tables. Applications of multiple decrement theory. Asset shares. Business and regulatory considerations.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; and one of Statistics 323 or Mathematics 323; and one of Mathematics 311 or 313 or 353 or 367 or 375 or 381; and one of Computer Science 217 or 231 or 235.
antireq: Credit for Actuarial Science 627 and 527 will not be allowed.

name: Credibility Theory
description: Limited fluctuation credibility; full and partial credibility; greatest accuracy credibility; Bayesian methodology; credibility premium; Buhlmann model; Buhlmann-Straub model; empirical Bayes method; bonus-malus system.
prereq: Actuarial Science 327; Statistics 323 or Mathematics 323; and one of Mathematics 311 or 313 or 353 or 367 or 375 or 381.
antireq: Credit for more than one of Actuarial Science 537, 637 and 533 will not be allowed.
notes: Actuarial Science 437 or Statistics 437 is strongly recommended as a prerequisite.

name: Cnfrn'c Course Actuarial Model
description: Topics in advanced actuarial theory and practice, such as: insurance risk models; practical analysis of extreme values; advanced property and casualty rate making; actuarial aspects of financial theory.

name: Introduction Academic Writing
description: An introduction to academic writing and to the genres of narrative, critical, and essay writing. Emphasis on developing an effective writing process, reading critically, developing arguments, and using and citing sources. Some emphasis on oral presentations may be included.

name: Introduction Academic Writing
description: An introduction to academic writing and to the genres of narrative, critical, and essay writing. Emphasis on developing an effective writing process, reading critically, developing arguments, and using and citing sources. Some emphasis on oral presentations may be included.

name: Introduction Academic Writing
description: An introduction to academic writing and to the genres of narrative, critical, and essay writing. Emphasis on developing an effective writing process, reading critically, developing arguments, and using and citing sources. Some emphasis on oral presentations may be included.

name: Introduction Research Writing
description: An introduction to inquiry-based research writing, from formulating good research questions to conducting an information search, developing an argument, using sources effectively, and revising and editing. A focus on oral presentations may also be included.

name: Introduction Research Writing
description: An introduction to inquiry-based research writing, from formulating good research questions to conducting an information search, developing an argument, using sources effectively, and revising and editing. A focus on oral presentations may also be included.

name: Introduction Research Writing
description: An introduction to inquiry-based research writing, from formulating good research questions to conducting an information search, developing an argument, using sources effectively, and revising and editing. A focus on oral presentations may also be included.

name: Discipline-based ACWR
description: An intermediate level course in the writing styles, genres and modes of evidence and reasoning appropriate to academic writing in a specific discipline or disciplines. Emphasis on connections between reading, writing, critical reasoning and, where appropriate, other discourse forms such as oral and electronic presentation.

name: Introduction to AFST
description: An inter/multidisciplinary study of the African continent, its people, culture and ecology with emphasis on the historic, socio-cultural, economic and political diversity within the continent.

rules.name: Credit for African Studies 201 and 301 will not be allowed.

name: Intro to African Studies
description: An interdisciplinary perspective on the people and ecologies of the African continent. The major theme will be the processes and effects of social, religious, political, economic, historical and cultural change on the lives of Africans.

name: Anti- Black Racism North Amrca
long_name: Anti- Black Racism in North America
description: Critical examination of the concepts and theories of anti-Black racism in North America and the intersections of gender, race, ethnicity, class, culture, politics and power, and privilege and inequality in the context of transnational migration.

name: Critical Cntmp'y Issues Africa
description: Analysis of critical issues and themes of contemporary importance, which may include governance and democratization, human rights, resource extraction (e.g., energy, mining) and the environment, democratization, poverty and inequality, health, social movements, conflict, migration and refugees, and the continent's dynamic and changing relations with the world.

name: Intro African/Black Diaspora
description: An inter/multidisciplinary examination of the evolution, and the diverse histories, cultures, identities, experiences and contribution of African/Black Transnational/Diaspora communities worldwide (e.g., African transnational, Black/African Diaspora in the Americas, Caribbean, Europe, Middle East and Asia.

name: Field Study in Africa
description: A field course for interdisciplinary study of a country or region of Africa, emphasizing the geographical, archaeological, historical, cultural, political, economic and artistic aspects.
notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees may be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

rules.name: Consent
rules.notes: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

name: Field Study in Africa
description: A field course for interdisciplinary study of a country or region of Africa, emphasizing the geographical, archaeological, historical, cultural, political, economic and artistic aspects.
notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees may be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: Topics in African Studies
description: Interdisciplinary course on topics within the field of African Studies.
prereq: 3 units from the Field of African Studies.

name: Topics African & Transnational
long_name: Topics in African and African Transnational Studies
description: An in-depth investigation of topics in African Diaspora and Transnationalism. Topics and content in any given year varies and depends on the instructor.
prereq: African Studies 201 or 301; and 3 units from the Field of African Studies.

name: Capstone Seminar in AFST
description: Study of a particular topic(s) or region(s) from an interdisciplinary and comparative perspective. Students will be required to examine how political, social, economic and cultural factors intersect to shape various issues in the African setting.
prereq: 9 units from the Field of African Studies, of which, 3 units must be from African Studies 201, 301, Anthropology 317, 320.

name: Beginners' Arabic I
description: A comprehensive course for students with no prior knowledge of the language. Includes training in listening, speaking, reading and writing of Modern Standard Arabic in its cultural context.
prereq: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
notes: See 4.59 Placement in Language Courses.

rules.name: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Beginners' Arabic II
description: Continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 202.

name: Reading Classical Arabic
description: An introduction to Arabic grammar and syntax through readings of classical sources.

name: Continuing Arabic I
description: A comprehensive course that includes further training in listening, speaking, reading and writing Modern Standard Arabic in its cultural context. Development of increased sophistication in language production and cultural understanding.

name: Continuing Arabic II
description: A continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 301.

name: Arabic Culture Immrs'n Setting
long_name: Arabic Culture in an Immersion Setting
description: Introduction to contemporary Arabic culture through research projects and life experience in an Arabic-speaking country.
notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: Modern Standard Arabic Lang
description: Stresses oral skills and cultural understanding in an immersion setting in an Arabic-speaking country. While the focus will be on speaking and aural comprehension, reading and writing will also be covered.
notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: Reading Classical Arabic
description: An introduction to Arabic grammar and syntax through readings of classical sources.

name: Muslim Civilization I
description: Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia and the West up to the end of the 18th century.

name: Muslim Civilization II
description: Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia, and the West focusing on the developments of the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries.

name: Topics in Muslim Civilization
description: Comparative study of Muslim civilization from Africa, the Arab and Persianate world, Asia, and the West focusing on the developments of the nineteenth, twentieth and twenty-first centuries.
notes: Taught in English. May be repeated for a maximum credit of 9 units.

name: Intermediate Arabic I
description: A comprehensive course that increases the command of the structure of modern standard Arabic through reading materials; develops reading and writing skills and comprehension. Development of increased sophistication in language production and cultural understanding.

name: Intermediate Arabic II
description: A continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 331.

name: Topics Intermediate Arabic II
description: Increases reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills in Modern Standard Arabic through the study of a given topic. Topics may include Arabic news media, literature, and historical texts. A continuation of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures 331.

name: Topic Colloquial Spoken Arabic
long_name: Topics in Colloquial Spoken Arabic I
description: Introduction to the everyday spoken language used in a particular Arabic-speaking country or region. Spoken varieties of Arabic taught may include Egyptian, Levantine, Gulf Varieties, and North African.

name: Egyptian
description: Introduction to the everyday spoken language used in Arabic-speaking countries.

name: Levantine
description: Introduction to the everyday spoken language used in Arabic-speaking countries.

name: Gulf Varieties
description: Introduction to the everyday spoken language used in Arabic-speaking countries.

name: Moroccan
description: Introduction to the everyday spoken language used in Arabic-speaking countries.

name: Tpc Colloquial Spk'n Arabic II
long_name: Topics in Colloquial Spoken Arabic II
description: A continuation of the everyday spoken language used in a particular Arabic-speaking country or region. Spoken varieties of Arabic taught may include Egyptian, Levantine, Gulf Varieties, and North African.

long_name: Directed Studies in Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures

long_name: Topics in the Study of Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures
description: Study of topics in the fields of Arabic language, literature, or culture, or Muslim cultures.
prereq: 3 units in a course labelled Arabic Language and Muslim Cultures at the 300 level or above.

name: Intro Biological Anthropology
description: Introduction to the major fields of biological anthropology including evolutionary theory and processes, human paleontology, primatology, genetics, osteology, human adaptation, development, and variation, with special emphasis on the path of human evolution.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 201 and Archaeology 203 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Anthropology 201 and Archaeology 203 will not be allowed.

name: IntroductionSocialAnthropology
long_name: Introduction to Social and Cultural Anthropology
description: Introduction to the study of human society and culture with the focus on major institutions (such as politics, economics, religion, kinship, and gender), operating on both local and global scales.

name: Dvlm't Indigenous Rln's Canada
long_name: Development of Indigenous Relations in Canada
description: An exploration of Indigenous relations in Canada, from an anthropological perspective, from first contact to present, including the development of Indian policy, the Indian Act, treaties, residential schools, and Sixties Scoop.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 210 and 213 will not be allowed.

name: ContempAboriginalIssuesCanada
description: An exploration of the history of Aboriginal state relations, the development of Indian policy, and current efforts of Aboriginal peoples to address historical matters through the critique of the reserve system, residential schools and the pursuit of self-government, land claims, modern treaties and Aboriginal rights.

name: Business in Cultural Context
description: Ways in which differences in cultural values and practices affect the form and nature of interaction between business parties, especially those of differing national/cultural/ethnic backgrounds.

name: Human Variation and Adaptation
description: Some of the major problems involved in interpreting modern and recent human diversity. Emphasis on the interaction between human cultural and biological systems and on cultural influences upon human biological diversity.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 305 and Archaeology 305 will not be allowed.

name: IntroductionToAnthStatistics
description: The basic techniques and applications of statistics in Anthropology.

name: Human Evolution
description: Investigation of the major phases of human evolution, with an emphasis on understanding how, when and why specific adaptations evolved. In laboratories, students learn to reconstruct behaviour from anatomical and palaeontological evidence.

name: Cntmpr'y Indigenous Issues Can
description: Investigation of current issues concerning Canada's Indigenous peoples, including land claims, self-government, Indigenous rights, health, education, housing, employment and other social issues.

name: EthnoSurveyOfNativeNAmerica
long_name: Ethno Survey Of Native N America

name: Primate Behaviour
description: Primate behaviour and related topics, including social dynamics, sociobiology, socio-ecology, dominance, aggression, kinship, sexual behaviour, socialization, learning, cognition, communication, ape language, and conservation.

name: Anthropology of Environment
description: Cross-cultural perspectives on human-environment relationships and application to contemporary problems concerning conservation, resource management and environmentalism.

name: EthnoSurveyOfNwCoastIndians
long_name: Ethno Survey Of Nw Coast Indians
description: Comparative survey of the organization of military institutions and their relationship with the larger society, based on historical and ethnographic sources.

name: WorldSurveyMilitaryInstitution
description: Comparative survey of the organization of military institutions and their relationship with the larger society, based on historical and ethnographic sources.

name: Ethno Survey Africa S Sahara
long_name: Ethnographic Survey of Africa South of the Sahara
description: Traditional societies in sub-Saharan Africa, concentrating on a number of classical social anthropological fieldwork studies.

name: Ethno Survey of North Africa
description: Ethnographic survey of the peoples of North Africa, including the Sahara, and historical analysis of their incorporation within the contemporary national states of the region.

name: Ethnographic Overview Africa
description: Ethnographic survey of the peoples of Africa and historical analysis of their incorporation within the contemporary nation states of the continent.

name: Ethno Overview Latin America
description: A survey of cultural traditions of Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central and South America as they have evolved since the 16th century.

name: Culture and Society of China
description: Diversity of social and cultural patterns in imperial and contemporary times.

name: Culture And Society Of Korea
description: Survey of the peoples, cultures and societies of the Korean peninsula.

name: Culture&SocietyOfModernJapan
description: Sources of Japanese identity: historical introduction; dynamic interaction between culture and personality; social structure and religion; how traditional values have shaped social and scientific modernization; sources of problems in cross-cultural communication.

name: EthnographicSrvySlctdWrldAreas
long_name: Ethnographic Survey of Selected World Areas
description: Arranged for various topics in the anthropology of world areas. Consult department for topics in any given year.

name: Topics Ethnographic Overview
long_name: Topics in Ethnographic Overview of Selected World Areas
description: Selected topics in the anthropology of world areas.

name: Cont Peoples Asia Ex Far East
long_name: Cont Peoples Asia Ex Far East

long_name: Peoples Of Asia Excl Of Far East

name: Sex and Gender
description: Cross-species and cross-cultural perspective on sex and gender.

name: Working in Anthropology
description: Introduction to the practical use of anthropological knowledge and research methods. Includes discussion of the specific challenges of practicing anthropology outside of academia.

name: Cult&EnvirSelCircumpolarPeop
description: Peoples and cultures of the circumpolar area with an emphasis upon environmental adaptation and the effects of culture contact.

name: IndigenousKnowledge&GlobalDev
description: Contemporary anthropological approaches to indigenous knowledge and peoples, particularly in their relationships to industrial and post-industrial societies.

name: Medical Anthropology
description: A survey of anthropological approaches to disease, illness and the maintenance of health.

name: Militarism and Militarization
description: Comparative global ethnographic survey of militarization processes. Examples will be drawn from contemporary and historical societies, with a particular emphasis on the wide variety of institutions and communities necessary to the production of violence, and on their relationship to the larger society.
antireq: Not open to students with credit in ANTH 315.

name: SurvOfPeople&CultMountAreas
long_name: Surv Of People & Cult Mount Areas

name: SurveyPeopleCultSelMtnRegion
long_name: Survey People Cult Sel Mtn Region

name: Dvlpm't INDG-Settler Rln's Can
long_name: Development of Indigenous-Settler Relations in Canada
description: An exploration of Indigenous-Settler relations in Canada from first contact to present, including the development of Indian policy, the Indian Act, treaties, residential schools, and Sixties Scoop.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 213 and 346 will not be allowed.

name: Anthropology of HIV/AIDS
description: Examines the individual, clinical, epidemiological, cultural, social, psychological, political, economic, and public policy dimensions of HIV/AIDS along with its meaning and importance on a global level from an anthropological perspective.
antireq: Credit for both Anthropology 349 and 399.01 will not allowed.

name: Lab Practice Biological Anthro
description: Examines the basic concepts and methods of biological anthropology using an experiential learning model. Coverage includes genetics, osteology, primatology, paleoanthropology, and human biology with a strong emphasis on the role of evolutionary theory throughout.

name: Primate Evolution
description: Focus on cladistic methods in taxonomy and theory in systematics and evolution. Discussion of major problems in primate evolution. Laboratory work involving cladistic analyses of fossil primate lineages.

name: Indigenous Peoples of Canada
description: A critical overview of the historical, social, political, economic, environmental, and cultural contexts related to health, justice, education, gender, traditional practices, and identity of Indigenous Peoples, Nations, cultures, and organizations across Canada.

name: Applied Anthropology
description: Introduction to the practical use of anthropological knowledge and research methods. Includes discussion of the specific challenges of practicing anthropology outside of academia.

name: Anthropology of Development
description: Cultural dimensions of local and international development policy, programming, and evaluation.
prereq: 3 units from Anthropology 203, Development Studies 201, Indigenous Studies 201.

name: History of Anthropology
description: Historical survey of anthropological thought from the enlightenment to the present.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 361 and 461 will not be allowed.

name: Magic, Witchcraft & Gods
long_name: Magic, Witchcraft, and Gods: Anthropology of Religion
description: Contemporary anthropological theoretical perspectives on topics such as divination, ritual, witchcraft, magic and symbolism in both Indigenous and world religions. The relationship of religion to healing, gender and power is also examined.

name: Anthropological Theory
description: Study of a variety of theories in Social and Cultural Anthropology, and their implications for research design and fieldwork.

name: RitualAndCulturalPerformance
description: Anthropological theories of political, social, symbolic and performative aspects of ritual and the role of ritual in the reproduction and contestation of cultural identities.

name: Political Anthropology
description: Comparative analysis of power, authority, dependency relations, and processes of governance, from the perspective of social anthropology, with primary emphasis on stateless societies and formative states.

name: Political Anthropology
description: Critical analysis of political structures and processes that illuminate connections between culture, politics, and economics.

name: Anthropology Of Law
description: Systems of law and social control in both state and non-state societies.

name: Anthropology of Law
description: Systems of law and social control in both state and non-state societies.

name: Urban Anthropology
description: A study of tribalism, ethnicity, sub-cultures, social networks and related phenomena in urban societies. Attention will be paid to planning and applied urban anthropology.

name: Nature Of Ethnographic Writing
description: Paradoxes of the boundary between fiction and non-fiction, contrasting the poetics and Aliterary features of conventional ethnography with the factuality and analytical power of ethnic novels and stories. Between these two extremes, a variety of intermediate or Ablurred genres (personal diaries, experimental anthropology, etc.) will be identified and explored.

name: Economic Anthropology
description: Comparative analysis of production, distribution and consumption in small-scale and complex societies; theories of exchange; effects of capitalism upon traditional economies and social organization.

name: Economic Anthropology
description: Comparative analysis of production, distribution and consumption in local and globalized contexts. Examines theories of exchange, the effects of capitalism, and the relation between economy and culture.

name: EthnographyGlobal-LocalDynamic
description: Changes in the international division of labour and resulting social, cultural, and political effects, with particular attention to the incorporation of small-scale societies.

name: Anthropological Theory
description: Study of a variety of theories in Social and Cultural Anthropology, and their implications for research design and fieldwork.
antireq: Credit for both Anthropology 391 and 365 will not be allowed.

name: Anthropology of Global Systems
description: Investigates the complex relationship between the global and the local by examining the social, cultural, economic, and political changes in specific localities as a result of the global rise of capitalism.

name: Anthropology of Science
description: An introduction to the culture and the politics of science. Examines conceptual and daily practices in the laboratory, the scientific method, the training of scientists, the work of scientific collaboration and the intersection between scientists and wider political, racial, gendered and religious issues. Special consideration will be given to the anthropology of scientific controversy.

description: Selected topics in anthropology to be offered Majors and Honours in their fourth year. Topics for each student to be arranged on the basis of special interest and need. For Honours students, submission of an acceptable honours essay is required for completion of the honours program and this course.

name: Ecol Tropical Forest Societies
description: Adaptation of indigenous societies to their tropical forest habitat, and their transformation under the impact of industrial society.

name: Cntmpr'y INDG Affairs Canada
description: Investigation of current affairs related to First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples, communities and Nations, including an examination of the historical, social, political, cultural and economic contexts of racism, colonialism and Indigenous strengths, resistance and resurgence.
prereq: 3 units from Anthropology 210, 213, 346, 355 or courses labelled Indigenous Studies.

name: Methods & Analysis for ANTH
description: An introduction to research design, data collection, and analysis as used in anthropology. Cross-cultural research design and methods, use of participant observation and personal documents will be emphasized.

name: The Primate Fossil Record
description: A review of the evolution of the primates, covering the morphological and taxonomic diversity of fossil primates, environmental and chronological context for primate evolution, and current debates and problems in the field of primate evolution. In class laboratories focus on the diversity of primate dietary, locomotor, and social adaptations, and how these are inferred from the fossil record.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 412 and 505.11 will not be allowed.

name: MethodAndTheoryInPrimatology
description: Focus on observational methods and analysis, with practical application in laboratory study at the Calgary Zoo. Theoretical perspectives of behavioural ecology as applied to primate studies.

name: Methods in Primatology
description: Focus on observational methods and analysis, with practical application in laboratory study at the Calgary Zoo.
notes: A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: EthnogAnalyNWCoastIndCult
long_name: Ethnog Analy N W Coast Ind Cult

name: (Arky419)Tipi,Buffalo & Vision
long_name: (Arky 419)Tipi, Buffalo, and Vision: People of the Plains
description: From the Blackfoot in the North to the Apache in the south, the lifeways of Plains people were incredibly diverse, including the iconic buffalo hunting people of the western Plains as well as the horticultural people of the eastern Plains. Explores traditional Plains culture as recorded in anthropological ethnographies, early European written accounts, and First Nations oral traditions.

name: Contemp Latin American Society
description: An examination of selected issues in the anthropological study of contemporary Latin America.

name: Primate Cognition
description: Causes and consequences of primate sociality, such as brain structure and evolution, kin recognition, Theory of Mind, social perception and awareness, and similarities and differences in communication and cognition between human and non-human primates.

name: Women in East Asian Societies
description: Comparison of women's roles in China, Japan, and Korea, with particular reference to family structure and economic organization.

name: Ethnography as Text
description: Written and pictorial techniques used by anthropologists in classic and experimental ethnographies to establish their authority and to persuade readers that the facts and patterns they report have an objective existence.
prereq: Anthropology 203, 391 and 393, or consent of the Department.

name: Applied Anthropology
description: Introduction to the practical use of anthropological knowledge and research methods. Includes discussion of the specific challenges of practicing anthropology outside of academia.
antireq: Credit for both Anthropology 433 and 357 will not be allowed.

name: Evolution of Human Behaviour
description: Analysis of evolutionary principles and processes (such as natural selection, sexual selection, kin selection, parental investment) as they are applied to the current study of human and non-human primate behaviour. Special emphasis on socioecological approaches to primate behaviour.

name: Problems in the Anth of Health
long_name: Problems in the Anthropology of Health
description: An examination of selected problems in the anthropology of health. Topics may include models of health in Canada, etiological claims in health research, and anthropology of pharmaceuticals.

name: ECOL & Behaviour Small Society
long_name: Ecology and Behaviour of Small-Scale Human Societies
description: Survey of the ethnographic record of small-scale societies from a biocultural and evolutionary perspective. Topics include energy systems, subsistence, social organization, learning, psychology, institutions, kinship structures, aggression and warfare, exchange, and interactions between state and non-state societies.

name: Anthropology of HIV/AIDS
description: Examines the individual, clinical, epidemiological, cultural, social, psychological, political, economic, and public policy dimensions of HIV/AIDS along with its meaning and importance on a global level from an anthropological perspective.

name: Primate Ecology & Conservation
description: An exploration of conservation challenges for nonhuman primates including how primates interact with their environments, the causes for population declines, and the strategies to reduce the threats to their survival.

name: Palaeoprimatology
description: Examination of the fossil primates, construction of evolutionary models and cladistic scenarios. Techniques for the reconstruction of ecological relationships, behaviour, and social structures of primate lineages.

name: History of Anthropology
description: Historical survey of anthropological thought from the enlightenment to the present.

name: Identity,Nation&Post-Colonial
description: A study of the creation of colonial national identities and their disruption by indigenous assertions of identity and sovereignty in settler societies including Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

name: Disaster Studies
description: Examines disasters in the Anthropocene with the goal of assessing human and environmental vulnerability, risk perception, and risk mitigation across cultures and political realms.
prereq: Anthropology 203 and 3 units in courses labelled Anthropology at the 300-level or above.

rules.name: Courses labelled Anthropology at the 300-level or above.

rules.value: Credit for Anthropology 466 and 399.15 (Disaster Studies) will not be allowed.

name: Soldiering:PersonMilitaryLife
description: An anthropological approach to soldiering in the aftermath of the Second World War. Questions the idea of a universal soldier, soldiers' shifting relationship to the nation-state, the rise of privatized warfare and the creation of global military communities. Special attention will be paid to the rise of humanitarian military regimes, military occupation, new techologies of warfare and non-human soldiers.

name: Ritual & Cultural Performance
description: Anthropological theories of political, social, symbolic and performative aspects of ritual and the role of ritual in the reproduction and contestation of cultural identities.

name: Peasants
description: A social anthropological analysis of political, economic and other aspects of diverse peasant societies.

name: Political Anthropology
description: Comparative analysis of power, authority, dependency relations, and processes of governance, from the perspective of social anthropology, with primary emphasis on stateless societies and formative states.

name: Belief Systems
description: An anthropological approach to the social construction of reality: the internal logic and structure of closed systems of ideas; processes of legitimization of belief; the resolution of contradictions; and properties of belief systems under conditions of social change.

name: Anthropology of Law
description: Systems of law and social control in both state and non-state societies.
prereq: Anthropology 203, 391 and 393, or consent of the Department.

name: Comp Study Of Kinship & Family
description: An introduction to theories of kinship, marriage, family, and gender; their manifestations in diverse cultural and social settings.

name: Housing and Society
description: Examines interactions between housing and social organization in cross-cultural context. Emphasizes the varied types of built form, their cultural meanings, implications for social life within households and for society more broadly, and their political and economic consequences. Pays particular attention to contemporary housing problems such as homelessness and urban sprawl.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 479 and Geography 479 will not be allowed.

name: Environment, Society & Culture
description: The relationship between human societies and the physical environment will be examined with emphasis on the relation between cultural behaviour and environmental phenomena.
coreq: Prerequisite or Corequisite: One of the following ethnographic courses: Anthropology 317, 319, 321, 323, 327, 331, 335, 427, Archaeology 345, 355, 357, 419.

name: Economic Anthropology
description: Comparative analysis of production, distribution and consumption in small-scale and complex societies; theories of exchange; effects of capitalism upon traditional economies and social organization.

name: Anthropological Theory
description: Examination of the fundamentals of anthropological theory through key concepts in anthropology since the nineteenth century, such as race, history, society, function, structure, gender and representation.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 391, 365 and 490 will not be allowed.

name: Anthropological Genetics
description: Examines the principles of evolutionary genetics with a focus on applications to current topics in Anthropology such as behaviour, life history, adaptation, migration and disease. Explores the contents of the primate genome as well as human and non-human primate genetic variation in an evolutionary framework.
prereq: 60 units including Anthropology 350 and consent of the Department.

name: Bio ANTH Perspectives Health
description: The biocultural study of human health among contemporary and past populations via cross-cultural studies of health and healing, child growth and development, reproductive health, aging, infectious disease, immune function, and the impact of stress on physical and mental health.

name: Hist &Thry Prmtlgy & Biol Anth
long_name: History and Theory in Primatology and Biological Anthropology
description: Historical and theoretical survey of ideas about the biological bases of human and non-human primate social behaviour. Impacts of the theoretical models of the modern synthesis, ethology, behavioural ecology, socio-ecology, and sociobiology or the study of human and non-human primates.

name: Anthropology Of Missions

name: Adv Studies in Visual Culture
description: Advanced studies in visual communication with special attention to historical and theoretical aspects of visual practices. Students will explore diverse expressions of visuality and undertake applied visual research and production. Topics may include the social production of visual discourse, visual media and social change, visual anthropology, and strategies for visual research.

name: Honours Seminar Bio Anthro
description: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format.

description: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format, with the possibility of development of a research project.

name: Nutritional Anthropology
description: The study of human dietary practices from biological and cultural perspectives. Subjects covered include the development of nutritional anthropology, principles of nutrition, principles of ecology, diet from an evolutionary, comparative and historic perspective, the impact of undernutrition on human physiology, and behaviour and methods in nutritional anthropology.
antireq: Credit for Anthropology 589 and Archaeology 589 will not be allowed.

description: Training and practice in research/teaching skills: grantsmanship, conference and classroom presentations, academic publishing, job interviews.
antireq: Not open to students with credit Anthropology 601.90 or the equivalent.
notes: Not open to students with credit in Anthropology 601.90 or the equivalent.

name: Methods In Anth Research
description: A variety of topics relevant to research and the logic of inquiry in Anthropology.

name: IssuesMethodology&Primatology
description: A variety of topics relating to aspects of data collection and data analysis in primatology, with a focus on ecological and behavioural data.

name: Primatological Theory
description: Seminar dealing with the theoretical material of primatological and biobehavioural perspectives in Anthropology.

name: Sem Civil-Military Reltns
description: Comparative analysis of relations between civil society and military institutions. A critical approach to analyzing how civil and military institutions mutually constitute each other, rather than taking the military and civilian sectors as a given. Special attention will be paid to twentieth century militarization as a social process that has dramatically changed the shape of both civilian and military spheres.

name: Primatological Theory
description: Specialized topics and laboratory training in this field will vary from year to year and may include: behavioural ecology, biomechanics, evolution, biosociality, and field methodology.

name: Social Anthropology
description: Specialized topics in this field will vary from year to year and may include: political, economic, or legal anthropology, race relations, peasant societies, and kinship theory.

name: Applied Anthropology
description: Specialized topics in this field will vary from year to year and may include: medical, educational, developmental aspects of anthropology, policy analysis, urban research, and applied race relations.

long_name: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

name: Special Topics in APLA
long_name: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture

long_name: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture

name: Special Topics in APLA
long_name: Special Topics in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

name: Design Research Methods
description: An introductory overview to the variety of research strategies, methods and project-based inquiries pursued in the professional design disciplines of architecture, planning and landscape architecture. Design research requires creative and critical thinking in the pursuit of inquires as to how we shape our world, recognizing the intense complexities and emerging challenges to be addressed in the creation of buildings, cities, and landscapes.

name: Design Research Writing
description: Knowledge translation, written communication and dissemination are key skills for design researchers. Addresses effective writing approaches in the development of research proposals, research abstracts, conference presentations, research paper submissions for peer review, and thesis documentation.

name: Design Innovation
description: Examines theories, precedents and strategies at the heart of novel and innovative design research, design responses, and approaches to design practice. Introduces design entrepreneurship and innovation skills crucial to advancing the impact of design research and its far-reaching implications within the built environment.

name: Des Prac Res Proj Definition
description: Introduction to practice-based research in the design fields. Explores the differences between first professional degree training, traditional PhD research, and design-based creative practice research using Design Science Research methodologies. Students will progress in defining their doctoral research question through self-reflexive study and a critical interrogation of their existing professional expertise and experience.

name: Contexts Des Practice Research
description: Exploration of diverse design practice contexts and communities of practice essential to understanding and developing a research question. Precedent examination of design practices, approaches, and case studies via professional and academic publications are used to understand various social, political, economic, and cultural contexts impacting the student's research question. Students develop an understanding of how contexts impact the researcher, the research question, the choice of research methods, dissemination of research, and other aspects of practice-based research. Introduction to ethics training.

name: Strat Des Practice Research
description: Explores strategies for conducting practice-based research in the design disciplines. Design Science Research methods are used to refine the research question and develop practice-based research strategies and benchmarks within the context of an active professional practice. Emphasizes discussions regarding the relationship between the doctoral research activities and the student¿s professional practice explorations completed within the context of the research project. Students will develop their doctoral research proposal, work plan, and ethics application in advance of preparation for candidacy field of study examinations.

name: Topics Course in APLA
long_name: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

name: Topics Course in APLA
long_name: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture

long_name: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture

name: Topics Course in APLA
long_name: Topics Course in Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special topics in architecture, planning and landscape architecture.

name: ARCH & the Future of Cities
long_name: Architecture and the Future of Cities
description: An introduction to architecture as a creative and technical endeavor that shapes the spaces and places in which we live. An examination of the purposes, intentions, processes, and products of architecture and how they can positively impact climate change, social equity, and quality of life. Students will develop an understanding of the social, cultural, historical, technological, economic, and natural contexts influencing the design of buildings and cities.

name: Intro Arch Plan Landscp Arch
long_name: Introduction to Architecture, Planning and Landscape Architecture
description: An examination of the central concepts of architecture, planning and landscape architecture delivered in an online format.

name: DesignDigitalTech&BuiltEnviron
long_name: Design, Digital Technology and the Built Environment
description: An introduction to the fundamental principles underlying modern digital technology-based systems, from a design of the built environment perspective. Topics include The Attention Economy, Big Data, Surveillance Capitalism, Ambient Intelligence, the Internet of Things, Opaque and Transparent Algorithms, Biocreepiness, and Systems Thinking. No specific technical background is required. Participants will complete a design project on a topic of personal interest.

name: Arch&LifeCycleThnkg:ClimateChg
long_name: Architecture and Life Cycle Thinking: Climate Change and Beyond
description: An introduction to strategies for comparing building and product performance in relation to environmental impacts and contributions to climate change. Concepts of circular economy, life cycle analysis, embedded energy, recycling/reuse of building materials are explored through the lenses of resource depletion, carbon and water footprints and waste generation.

name: Design Thnkng Built Environ I
long_name: Design Thinking in the Built Environment Studio I
description: A foundational introduction to design thinking as applied to the built environment of buildings, cities, and landscapes. Students will complete a series of experiential learning exercises that emphasize three-dimensional thinking and problem-solving skills. The course is offered in a studio environment, which along with the course-work, will provide valuable experience to develop a portfolio.
antireq: Credit for Architecture 406 and any of Architectural Studies 484, Environmental Design Architecture 580, or Architecture 506 will not be allowed.

name: Design Thnkng Built Environ II
long_name: Design Thinking in the Built Environment Studio II
description: A capstone project-based course that builds on the skills acquired in Architectural Studies 431. Students will work in small groups to develop, research, execute, and present a small design thinking project based in Calgary. The course is offered in a studio environment.

name: Sustainability Built Environ
description: The principle of sustainability recognizes people as temporary stewards of their environments, working toward a respect for natural systems and a higher quality of life. Examination of the built environment and the tools to achieve a stable and balanced and a regenerative ecosystem in a process of responsible consumption, wherein waste is minimized and the built environment interacts with natural environments and cycles. Healthful interior environments, resource efficiency, ecologically benign materials, renewable energies and social justice issues are examined.
prereq: Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.

name: HistArch&HumanSettlements I
long_name: History of Architecture and Human Settlements I - Premodern Traditions of the World
description: A survey history of architecture and human settlement addressing the premodern traditions of the major world cultures. The course will examine the changes in world view that have altered the course of architecture through the study of selected works of architecture and urbanism.
prereq: Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 457.01 and Environmental Design Architecture 523.01)

name: Graphics Workshop I
description: A skill building course with instruction and supervised experience in basic drafting, sketching and rendering; principles of perspective, drawing and presentation conventions. A variety of instruction may be offered to accommodate the varied level of student development.
prereq: Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 451 and Environmental Design Architecture 541)

name: Studio I in Architecture
description: A studio that explores the foundation concepts in architectural design and form making involving a sequence of progress skill building, visual and spatial thinking and problem-solving exercises.
prereq: Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 484 and Environmental Design Architecture 580)

name: Building Science & Tech I
description: Functioning of the building enclosure: demonstration of the behaviour of building elements and their sub-assemblies under differential temperature and pressure stresses; fundamentals of acoustics; nature and use of building materials; response of building materials to climatic cycles radiation, precipitation, heating and cooling.
prereq: Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
antireq: Credit for Architecture 508 and Design 431 will not be allowed.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 449 and Environmental Design Architecture 511)

name: HistArch&HumanSettlements II
long_name: History of Architecture and Human Settlements II - The Rise of Modernity, 1750 to Present
description: A survey history of architecture and human settlement exploring the traditions of the Western world from the beginning of the Italian Renaissance until the present. The courses will examine the changes in world view that have altered the course of architecture through the study of selected works of architecture and urbanism.
prereq: Admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 457.02 and Environmental Design Architecture 523.02)

name: Graphics Workshop II
description: Instruction and supervised experience in drafting, sketching and rendering; drawing and presentation conventions. Builds on Architecture 504. A variety of instruction may be offered to accommodate the varied level of student development.
prereq: Architecture 504, 506 and admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 453 and Environmental Design Architecture 543)

name: Studio II in Architecture
description: A studio exploring the application of ordering principles of architecture and to the numerous layers that contributes to the quality of inhabitation of place and space through design. Issues explored include the formal, the experiential and the theoretical concerns of architectural design in today's cultural context.
prereq: Architecture 504, 506 and admission to the Minor in Architectural Studies or the Master of Architecture Programs.
aka: (formerly Architectural Studies 444 and Environmental Design Architecture 582)

name: Structures for Architects I
description: Fundamentals of Structural Analysis including the characteristics and performance of the various components of structures; the terminology and notation necessary for effective teamwork with structural engineering consultants; and basic design calculations for simple structures.

name: Intro to Design Theories
description: The contemporary cultural, social, and philosophical arenas in which architecture exists are examined through lectures, readings and seminars.

name: Leadership in Architecture
description: The practice of architecture deals with complex design requirements, diverse groups of people, changing processes, evolving contexts, and a range of modes of production. This course introduces students to a broad set of contemporary themes around the concept of leadership and architecture.

name: Inter Architectural Des Studio
description: An intermediate design studio in which students work on projects defined by the instructor. Topics may vary from year to year. They are determined by the creative interests of the faculty assigned to the course.

name: Architectural Lighting Design
description: Fundamentals of light and visual perception. Approaches to the design of non-uniform and uniform lighting systems for buildings. Issues in system design such as human satisfaction, performance, and energy efficiency. Development of skills in the selection and design of lighting systems.

name: Structures for Architects II
description: Advanced structural systems for buildings including: structural connections and composite structures; system characteristics and architectural intent; and case studies in contemporary building structures.

name: Build Science & Technology II
description: Theory and principles of structural, foundation and building service systems. Application of building science principles to building structure and enclosure, examination of the types and manufacture of building elements and the application of building components to specific problems in architecture.

name: Environmental Control Systems
description: Approaches to the design of heating, cooling, and ventilation systems for buildings. Issues in system design such as energy efficiency and indoor air quality.

name: Comp Architectural Des Studio
description: A comprehensive design studio in which students work on projects defined by the creative interests of the instructor.

name: Architectural Prof Practice
description: The nature of the building industry, stakeholders and many of the participants and their responsibilities. Brings together the theoretical framework of the architect's role in society with the practicality of managing a practice. Project management and office administration, trends, liabilities and systems for project control such as building economics; cost analysis and estimating techniques; and cost controls during design and construction.

name: Experiential Learning in Arch
description: Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in architecture.

name: Exp Learning in Architecture
description: Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in landscape architecture.

name: Experiential Learning in Arch
description: Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in architecture.

name: Experiential Learning in Arch
description: Thematic inquiry and design contextualized by experiential learning in architecture.

name: Urban Systems
description: Provides a general overview of urban history, development and planning traditions. Lectures and field studies give a chronological overview of urban, architectural and design history and the inter-relation to political programs, economic and strategic planning as well as cultural nationalism. Extracts a number of more general issues about contemporary cities for debate.

name: Urban Systems
description: Provides a general overview of urban history, development and planning traditions. Lectures and field studies give a chronological overview of urban, architectural and design history and the inter-relation to political programs, economic and strategic planning as well as cultural nationalism. Extracts a number of more general issues about contemporary cities for debate.

description: Provides a general overview of urban history, development and planning traditions. Lectures and field studies give a chronological overview of urban, architectural and design history and the inter-relation to political programs, economic and strategic planning as well as cultural nationalism. Extracts a number of more general issues about contemporary cities for debate.
