description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special studio topics in architecture.

name: Special Studio Topics in Arch
description: Thematic inquiry and design related to special studio topics in architecture.

name: Studio Research Selective
description: Provides additional expertise in an area of focus to support the work students complete in research studios. Topics and themes vary but include; Design Responses to Climate Change, Energy Performance, Historical Precedents and Theories, Designing for Social Equity and Inclusion, Life Cycle Analysis, Digital Fabrication, Simulation and Communication Techniques.

name: Gillmor Theory Seminar
description: Explores architectural history and theory as the context for the production of architecture and its artifacts. Students work with a visiting lecturer to develop design responses within a provided theoretical framework. Outputs may include manifestos, speculative projects, drawings, prototypes and exhibits.

name: Studio Research Selective
description: Provides additional expertise in an area of focus to support the work students complete in research studios. Topics and themes vary but include; Design Responses to Climate Change, Energy Performance, Historical Precedents and Theories, Designing for Social Equity and Inclusion, Life Cycle Analysis, Digital Fabrication, Simulation and Communication Techniques.

name: Somerville Design Charrette
description: Explores an architectural problem proposed by a visiting practicing architect. Exposes students to the work of an architectural practice and provides an opportunity for students to collaborate with the visiting lecturer on a speculative architectural project. Outputs include drawings, models and exhibits of the work completed during the course.

name: Taylor Workshop
description: Examines the role of computation and making in architecture. Explores these topics through a guided process of fabrication using contemporary design techniques. Outputs may include prototypes of various scales, drawings, digital workflows, installations and exhibits.

name: Senior Res Studio in Arch I
long_name: Senior Research Studio in Architecture I
description: A research design studio in which students collaborate with design faculty in exploring projects that engage contemporary issues defining the built and natural environments.

name: Senior Res Studio in Arch II
long_name: Senior Research Studio in Architecture II
description: A research design studio in which students collaborate with design faculty in exploring projects that engage contemporary issues defining the built and natural environments.

name: Directed Study in Architecture
description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to architecture design topics.

name: Directed Study in Architecture
description: Thematic research, readings, or studio projects related to architecture design topics.

name: Preceptorship in Architecture
description: A preceptorship is a study and training arrangement made between a student and an employer or an equivalent supervisor which has specific educational objectives, a method of evaluation, and is an integral part of a student's Program of Studies. Preceptorships offer a number of benefits: acquiring skills and knowledge which may be better obtained outside the University; developing first-hand experience of professional design practice; preparing for more focused studies in the School; and conducting research.

name: Introduction to Art History I
description: An examination of art and architecture before 1400 in relation to significant historical and cultural events.

name: Introduction to Art History II
description: An examination of art and architecture after 1400 in relation to significant historical and cultural events.

name: Art: WWII to the Present
long_name: Art: World War II to the Present
description: A chronological examination of Western art in relation to significant historical and cultural events from WWII to the present
prereq: Admission to the Visual Studies or Art History major programs.

name: Writing and Art History
description: An introduction to the techniques and strategies of writing about art and cultural objects within the discipline of art history. Students develop and strengthen their writing skills in relation to addressing, evaluating, and assessing art.

name: Art Of Canada: 1600-1900
description: Forms and concepts in art in Canada from the Early French and English Colonial periods to 1900.

name: ArtOfCanada:1900ToThePresent
long_name: Art Of Canada:1900 To The Present
description: Forms and concepts in Canadian art from 1900 to the present; the Group of Seven, Nationalism, Regionalism and more recent developments in Canadian art.

name: Architecture Of Canada To 1900
description: A chronological, thematic and regional examination of architectural developments in Canada to c.1900.

name: Canadian Art History
description: A critical analysis of the forms, objects, and practices that compose the art canon of northern North America. Organized thematically, this course covers the period of history ranging from European contact to the present day.
antireq: Credit for Art History 305 and either 301 or 303 will not be allowed.

name: ArchitectureOfCanadaSince1900
description: A chronological, thematic and regional examination of Canadian architecture since c.1900.

name: Survey Of Indigenous Arts
description: An introduction to the arts of the native peoples of Africa, Oceania, Pre-Columbia and North America. The definitions and roles of art within traditional society will be examined.

name: Topics ARHI & Visual Studies
long_name: Topics in Art History and Visual Studies
description: Key concepts and theories within the discipline of Art History. Topics may include: Feminist Art Histories; and Art and Social Critique.

name: EarlyMedieval:Christian-11thC
description: A chronological examination of the arts and architecture from the decline of the Roman Empire to the beginning of the Romanesque Age.

name: Art from 1880 - WW II(1939-45)
description: Forms and concepts in western art from the late 19th century to the Second World War (1939-1945).

name: HighMedieval:Romanesque&Gothic
description: A chronological examination of the arts and architecture from the 11th Century to about 1300 A.D. Special attention will be given to how the Romanesque and Gothic Cathedral reflect the great social, religious and philosophical synthesis of the Age.

name: The Arts Of Western Africa
description: A chronological and stylistic study of the arts of the various Western Sudanic peoples and the early historical cultures found in Mali, Ghana and Nigeria.

name: History of Photography
description: An examination of the development of photography as a technology, an art medium, and a way of envisioning the world. Historical antecedents of contemporary practices will be emphasized.
antireq: Credit for Art History 319 and either 419 and 423 will not be allowed.

name: ArtsOfCentral&SouthernAfrica
description: A chronological and stylistic study of the arts of central and southern Africa with emphasis upon their cultural context.

name: Medieval Art and Architecture
description: An examination of art and architecture c. 400- 1400.

name: FarEastArt:India&RelateCivil
long_name: Survey of Far Eastern Art: India and Related Civilizations
description: An examination of the art and architecture of ancient India and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Buddhist, Hindu and Islamic art.

name: China & Related Civilizations
description: An examination of the art and architecture of ancient China and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Confucian, Taoist and Buddhist art.

name: Renaissance Art
description: An examination of the arts and architecture of Europe from c. 1300-1600.
antireq: Credit for Art History 327 and 329 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Art History 327 and 329 will not be allowed.

name: High Renaissance & Mannerism
description: A chronological examination of the arts and architecture from about 1500 to the end of the sixteenth century. Special attention will be given to the key artistic personalities representing the High Renaissance and Mannerism in northern and southern Europe.

name: Modern Art and Architecture
description: A critical exploration of the development of and discussions about different art movements in relation to Modern Art and the avant-garde, addressing the historical circumstances that enabled the creation of selected art movements, which may include Impressionism, the Arts and Crafts Movement, Cubism, Surrealism, Pop Art, Fluxus, and Situationist.
antireq: Credit for Art History 331 and any of 405, 407 or 415 will not be allowed.

name: Contemporary Art Architecture
description: An introduction to the socio-political approaches and critical theories that have informed art-making in the contemporary period. Examines artworks and their production, circulation, and reception through a variety of positions including gender, race, sexuality, and post-coloniality.
antireq: Credit for Art History 333 and 209 will not be allowed.

name: Topics in Art and Technology
description: Examination of the development of art techniques and forms in relation to a variety of technologies. Topics may include the printing press, the history of video games, telematics, interactive art, and structures of surveillance.
antireq: Credit for Art History 340 and either Art History 341 or Art 311.01 will not be allowed.

name: Art and Technology
description: An examination of the development of art techniques and forms in relation to a variety of contemporary technologies. Topics may include the history of video games, history of telematic and interactive art, and structures of surveillance.
antireq: Credit for Art History 341 and Art 311.01 will not be allowed.

name: A History of Design
description: An introduction to the history of design including international movements, materials and technologies, production and consumption, and contemporary issues of critical design practice.

name: Baroque Art
description: An examination of the art and architecture of Europe during the seventeenth century.

name: 18th & 19th Century Art
description: An examination of the art and architecture in Europe and its colonies during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

name: Survey Far Eastern Art: Japan
long_name: Survey of Far Eastern Art: Japan
description: An examination of the art and architecture of dynastic Japan, with special emphasis on Shinto and Buddhist traditions.

name: Indigenous Art of the Americas
description: Historical and contemporary studies of indigenous cultural production within the geographic context of the Americas.

name: North&InuitSculptureCultCont
description: Focus on the three-dimensional artistic expression of the prehistoric to contemporary Eskimo and Inuit of Canada, Greenland and Alaska, based on Arctic cultural history and archaeology.

name: Art and Site
description: An exploration of the ways in space, place, and context influence the meanings and values of art objects. Topics may include the history of displays, street art, art and the environment, and art in public spaces and sacred sites, and monuments.

name: Artist Case Study
description: Introduction to case study methodology in Art History by way of an in-depth study of the work and life of a particular artist.

name: Late18th&Early19thCentArt
description: A chronological examination of European painting and sculpture from the late eighteenth century through the Romantic period.

name: MidLateNineteenthCenturyArt
description: A chronological examination of European painting and sculpture of the Realist, Impressionist and Post-Impressionist periods.

name: Topics in the History of Art
long_name: Topics in the History of Art
description: An in-depth examination of a particular topic related to the study of Art History.
prereq: 6 units of courses labelled Art History.

name: SelectedTopicsHistoryOfArtI
long_name: Selected Topics History Of Art I
description: Topics to be announced. Typical topics include: The Art of Michelangelo, Surrealism, Abstract Art in Canada, Painting in New York from WW II to Present, Art of the West African Sudan, The Canadian Landscape.
prereq: Three full-course equivalents in Art History or consent of the Department.

name: SelTopicsInHistoryOfArtII
long_name: Sel Topics In History Of Art II
description: Topics to be announced. Typical topics include: The Art of Michelangelo, Surrealism, Abstract Art in Canada, Painting in New York from WW II to Present, Art of the West African Sudan, The Canadian Landscape.
prereq: Three full-course equivalents in Art History or consent of the Department.

name: ModernArt:1880sTo1stWorldWar
description: Forms and concepts in painting, sculpture and architecture from the late 19th century to the advent of the First World War.

name: ModernArt:End1stWorldWar-1950
description: Study of the forms and concepts in painting, sculpture, and architecture from the end of the First World War through the 1950s.

name: PhotographyInThe19thCentury
description: Origins of photography and its development as technology and art up to 1900.

name: PhotographyInThe20thCentury
description: The development of photography from 1900 to the present, with attention to the theory and criticism of photography as an art form.

name: ArchitectureWWorldSince1900
long_name: Architecture in the Western World Since 1900
description: A survey of significant examples of modern architecture, defining their stylistic character in light of developments in technology, the history of ideas, and social and historical factors.

name: Art and the Body
description: A critical analysis of the power dynamics inherent to forms of looking and representations of the body in a variety of historical periods and geographical locations. May include gendered representations, the medicalized body, the body in classical art, and displays of marginalized bodies.
prereq: 3 units from Art History 331, 333, 357 and 3 additional units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above.

name: Graphic&TextileArtsOfInuit
description: An in-depth examination of the graphic and textile arts of the Canadian Inuit, including comparisons with these areas in Alaska and Greenland, based in part on Inuit legends and traditions.

name: Topics in Global Art
description: An advanced exploration of topics and issues relevant to art-making and exhibitions within global contexts. Topics may include World's Fairs, art biennales, outsider art, and souvenirs.
prereq: 6 units in courses labeled Art History at the 300 level or above.

name: Independent Research ARHI
description: Independent research projects for advanced students in art history.
prereq: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

rules.name: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.
rules.notes: o    Consent of the Department.

name: IndependentResInArtHistoryII
long_name: Independent Res In Art History II

name: Seminar In The History Of Art
long_name: Seminar In The History Of Art
description: Topics to be announced. Possible topics include: The Art of Bernini, Cubism, The Group of Seven in Canada.

name: Capstone in the History of Art
long_name: Capstone in the History of Art
description: A critical investigation of a particular subject related to the advanced study of Art History and Visual Culture.
prereq: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

name: Directed Studies Art History
description: An independent research project conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereq: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

name: Conference Course in ARHI
description: Focuses on close examinations and discussions of students' research and writing, with an emphasis on communicating informed research creation practices. The course will culminate in a conference presentation.

name: Introduction To Archaeology
description: Basic principles of archaeology. How archaeological remains are located, recovered and interpreted.
notes: A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: Intro To Physical Anthropology
description: Survey of the major subfields of physical anthropology including evolution, human paleontology, genetics, osteology and variation, and techniques of data collection.

name: World Archaeology
description: An overview of Old and New World archaeology; the emergence of humans; development of humans and culture from hunting/gathering to agricultural and ancient urban societies.

name: Archaeology of North America
description: Prehistoric cultural developments in North America.

name: LabCourseInTechniquesOfArky
long_name: Lab Course In Techniques Of Arky

name: LabCourseInTechniquesOfArky
long_name: Lab Course In Techniques Of Arky

name: LabCourseInTechniquesOfArky
long_name: Lab Course In Techniques Of Arky

name: Human Variation & Adaptation
description: Study of some of the major problems involved in interpreting modern and recent human diversity. Emphasis is placed on the interaction between human cultural and biological systems and on cultural influences upon human biological diversity. Factors important to archaeological interpretation will be stressed.

name: FieldCourseInArkyTechniques
description: Practical application of modern field techniques in archaeology, including excavation, recording and analysis of sites, artifacts and related materials.
notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: OriginOfCivilInEastHemispher
long_name: Origin Of Civil In East Hemispher

name: Intro to Ethnoarchaeology
description: Theory, method, ethics and the contributions of ethnoarchaeological research to archaeology and other disciplines are explored using worldwide examples.

name: OriginsOfCivilInWestHemisphe
long_name: Origins Of Civil In West Hemisphe

name: Arky of Ancient Puebloan SW
long_name: Archaeology of the Ancient Puebloan Southwest
description: Survey of the puebloan archaeology of southwestern North America and their pre-puebloan ancestors. Topics include changes in hunter-gatherer mobility and economy, the rise of agriculture in the American Southwest, the rise of integrative communities and religious belief systems, as well as responses to violence, disease, climate change, and the immigration of non-Puebloan outsiders.
antireq: Not for credit with Archaeology 427.

name: Early People In The Old World
long_name: Early People In The Old World

name: Archaeology of the Plains
description: Introduction to Canadian Plains archaeology. Processes of cultural and social change on the northern plains over the last 12,000 years from early hunters of Ice--Age megafauna to tribal level farming societies are explored from a Canadian Plains perspective.

name: Early Man In The New World
long_name: Early Man In The New World

name: Ancient Civilizations
description: The rise and achievements of the earliest civilizations in both the Old and New Worlds. Emphasis will be placed on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, India, China, Mesoamerica and the Andes.

name: Topics ARKY & Popular Culture
long_name: Topics in Archaeology and Popular Culture
description: Archaeology is examined in terms of its place in contemporary society. Topics may include the use of archaeological evidence by special interest groups; archaeology as viewed by the media; ethical questions relating to the practice of archaeology.

name: Topics in Archaeology
description: Examination of contemporary developments in the field of Archaeology. Topics may be drawn from theoretical, methodological, ethical, or regional research frontiers and may critically address the role of archaeology in contemporary society.

name: Fringe Archaeology
description: Explores popular, fantastic and alternate interpretations of archaeological remains presented in the press and popular media and analyzes the logical flaws in pseudoscientific explanations. Students hone their critical thinking skills and discover the \"real story\" about our past revealed by the science of archaeology.
antireq: Credit for both Archaeology 329 and 327.01 (Frauds, Myths & Mysteries) will not be allowed.

name: Archaeology and the Media
description: Explores how the ancient world, human evolution, archaeologists, and archaeology are represented in a range of media (e.g. films, books, video games, websites, newspapers). Examines how archaeologists use digital media and social media sites to conduct research, as well as disseminate information to Indigenous communities and the general public.
antireq: Credit for Archaeology 331 and 327.02 (Archeology and the Media) will not be allowed.

name: Becoming Human
description: An introduction to human biological and cultural evolution. Brings together Paleolithic, archaeological, biological, geological and Paleoecological evidence to provide a holistic overview of the path to humanity.
antireq: Credit for Archaeology 333 and either 327.03 or Anthropology 309 will not be allowed.

name: African Stone Age
description: Introduction to the African Stone Age, with emphasis on sub-Saharan Africa. Major cultural developments are explored through archaeological data, as well as other disciplines, including biogeography and geoarchaeology. Topics include early human origins and the behaviour of early humans during the middle Pleistocene, as well as the Later Stone Age. Focus on major chronological events and the cultural processes that characterize the Paleolithic era on the continent.

name: Ancient Mexico
description: Ancient cultures of Mexico, excluding the Maya, from their beginnings to the historic period. Emphasis on the civilizations of the Olmecs, Zapotecs, Teotihuacanos, Toltecs and Aztecs.

name: The Ancient Maya
description: Ancient Maya, from their beginnings to the historic period.Emphasis on the Classic Maya civilization, from AD 200-900.

name: The Legacy of Mesoamerica
description: Traditional native cultures of Middle America. Emphasis is on technology, social organization, economic systems, religions, arts and languages, particularly in the culture centres of Mexico.

name: Field Study Latin Am ARKY
long_name: Field Studies in Latin American Archaeology
description: A general survey of the archaeology of the region and an intensive look at the archaeology of the immediate vicinity, including visits to sites and museums. Content varies according to region in Latin America where course is taught. Individual and group study are interspersed with formal instruction.
notes: May be offered as part of a group study program. Additional fees may be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: Arky S A: Lowlands & N Andes
long_name: Archaeology of South America: The Lowlands and the Northern Andes
description: Prehistoric cultural development in the tropical areas of South America with particular emphasis on the Amazon Basin.

name: Archaeology of South America
description: Reviews the major events and cultural processes in Pre-Columbian South America beginning with the first hunting cultures. Emphasis is on central and Andean and northern lowland South American civilizations.

name: Indian Of S A:Lowland & N Asia
long_name: Indian Of S A:Lowland & N Asia

name: Native Cultures of the Amazon
description: A survey of the culture and linguistics of aboriginal South America, with emphasis on the lowland regions.

name: The Incas and Their Successors
description: Traditional cultures of the Ecuadorian, Peruvian and Bolivian Andes. Special emphasis is placed on the social, political and economic organizations of the Inca empire.

name: Ethn Of A Sel Non-America Area
long_name: Ethn Of A Sel Non-America Area

name: Ethn Of A Sel Non-America Area
long_name: Ethn Of A Sel Non-America Area

name: Ethn Of A Sel Non-America Area
long_name: Ethn Of A Sel Non-America Area

name: African Archaeology
description: African archaeology from the earliest times to the ethnographic present, particularly on Holocene cultures, including hunters and foragers, sedentary farmers, and urban societies.

name: African Historical Archaeology
description: Examples of African history are explored using the techniques found in African historical archaeology including oral history and traditions, ethnoarchaeology, genetics, archaeology, historical records and art history.

name: Archaeology of the Near East
description: Survey of the prehistory of the Near East, starting with the earliest traces of human activity up to the Bronze Age. The Near East is a small but dynamic region that witnessed many of the world's cultural firsts. Topics include adaptations to a varied environment, successive human migrations out of Africa, the nature of the Middle-Upper Palaeolithic transition, the agricultural revolution, and the world's earliest cities and states.
prereq: Archaeology 201 or 205 or consent of the Department.

name: Prehistory Of Europe
description: A survey of the prehistoric archaeology of Europe.

name: Mesoamerican Writing Systems
description: Overview of Mesoamerican writing systems, including Maya hieroglyphics. Topics include the origin and development of writing in Mesoamerica, as well as the evolution of the calendar and other notational systems. Introduction to methods of decipherment and current interpretations of the texts.
prereq: Archaeology 341 and 343 or consent of the Department.

name: (Geog413)SoilCharacter&Format
description: Characteristics of soils and the processes and factors of soil formation. Soil development related to geomorphic materials, geomorphic events, anthropogenic sources, and erosional and depositional landscapes.

name: Lithic Technology
description: Study and analysis of tools and other artifacts, including their forms, methods of manufacture and use.

name: Zooarchaeology
description: The study and analysis of osteological remains used in reconstructing the subsistence strategies of past peoples.

name: Indigenous Peoples of Plains
description: Explores traditional Plains cultures as recorded in ethnographic accounts and First Nations oral traditions.
antireq: Credit for Archaeology 419 and Anthropology 419 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Archaeology 419 and Anthropology 419 will not be allowed.

name: ArchaeologyOfTheGreatPlains
description: Comprehensive overview of the archaeology of the Plains area.

name: Archaeology of the Arctic
description: Prehistory/history of N. E. Asia, Alaska, Canada and Greenland. Emphasis will be placed on ecological and ethnographical data.

name: ArkySouthwesternNorthAmerica
description: A comprehensive survey of the archaeology of the Greater Southwest.

name: Oceanic Archaeology
description: The prehistory of New Guinea, Australia, Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia. Reviews the Southeast Asian origin of Oceanic cultures; the early peopling of New Guinea and Australia; the migration of people into the islands of the South Pacific and the development of Oceanic cultures to the end of the prehistoric period.
prereq: ARKY 201 or consent of the Department.

name: Arky of Eastern North America
description: Cultural developments in eastern North America from the earliest known human occupation to the advent of Europeans. Topics will include the changing adaptations of hunter-gatherers, the appearance of sedentism, the introduction/invention of horticulture, and the emergence of social complexity.
prereq: Archaeology 201 or consent of the Department.

name: African Stone Age
description: A study of human origins and prehistoric hominin behaviour on the African continent.

name: Paleolithic ARKY Old World
long_name: Paleolithic Archaeology in the Old World
description: A global survey of Old World prehistoric hunter-gatherers with an emphasis on factual data, analytical techniques, and interpretive trends in the study of the Paleolithic era.

name: African Complex Societies
description: Ancient African complex societies with an emphasis on state development south of the Sahara. Topics include why these states developed, their participation in internal and international systems of exchange, technological developments, belief systems that supported power structures, and the reasons for their collapse. Time period covered is from the rise of the ancient state of Egypt to the colonial period.

name: Ancn't Cities ARKY Perspective
description: Exploration of archaeological approaches to ancient cities and urbanism. Uses a cross-cultural perspective to examine features and functions of ancient cities, as well as historical and current theoretical and methodological used to interpret them, and their relevance to studies of modern cities and urbanism.
prereq: History 354 or 3 units labelled Archaeology or Urban Studies.

name: Later African Prehistory
description: Late Pleistocene and earlier Holocene developments throughout the continent. Topics include the consolidation of modern human behavior, Later Stone Age developments, the spread of modern humans out of Africa, the trend towards sedentism at the end of the Pleistocene, and the evolution and spread of food production, metallurgy and trade.
prereq: Archaeology 201 or 205 or consent of the Department

name: Hunter-Gatherer Archaeology
description: An overview of the history of hunter-gatherer studies in anthropology and archaeology. Introduces current theoretical issues in hunter-gatherer research.

name: Method & Theory in ARKY
description: A survey of approaches to the study of the relationship between theory, method, and data in archaeological practice.
prereq: Archaeology 201 and completion of at least 60 units.

rules.name: 60 units.
rules.notes:
• 60 units of courses

  • Some of these courses may be restricted to students who are enroled in particular majors and programs.

  • Not all of these courses are offered each year. Check the availability of courses by logging into your Student Centre.

name: Fundamentals of Geoarchaeology
description: Methods used in geoarchaeology to interpret site and regional context, provenance, stratigraphy, environmental and climatic changes, and principles applied in dating, chemical and isotopic analysis, and remote sensing. Basic principles of sedimentation and soil development explored in experiential learning modules.

name: Paleoindian Archaeology
description: Comprehensive overview of early hunter-gatherer archaeology in North and South America, including the Clovis/pre-Clovis debate, theoretical issues surrounding early hunting and mobility, the migration to the Americas during the last ice age, and cultural ecological dynamics.
prereq: Archaeology 201 or consent of the Department.

name: Ceramic Analysis
description: The production of pottery: raw materials and techniques. Form, function and decoration. Ceramic ecology. Field processing and sampling. Classification: a survey of approaches. Ceramics and archaeological inference. Practical exercises.

name: Current Topics in Archaeology
description: Examination of current theoretical, methodological, or topical issues in archaeology.

name: Problems of Hominid Evolution
description: A detailed investigation of the major problems which confront scholars in terms of hominid evolution. Several sub-disciplines of physical anthropology are considered.

name: PracticalProbInArkyInterpret
description: Exercises in the analysis and interpretation of a variety of archaeological data sets.

name: Gender in Prehistory
description: The theoretical background for feminist archaeology and some of the important advances in Old and New World
prereq: Archaeology 451 or consent of the Department.

name: Current Debates
description: Topics of debate in archaeology and human biology from a perspective that emphasizes philosophical, theoretical and methodological issues. Designed to hone students' critical, analytical, and debating skills, and as preparation for graduate studies.
notes: Archaeology 505 should be taken in the final year of the program.

long_name: Problems Of West African Iron Age

long_name: Prob In Arky Of Mid & S Amer:I

description: Training in the more advanced aspects of field work.
notes: A supplementary fee will be assessed to cover additional costs associated with this course.

name: Mesoamerican Writing Systems
description: Writing systems of Mesoamerica (especially the Maya), their origins and development, and including the Mesoamerican calendar and astronomical knowledge.

name: Comparative Writing Systems
description: A comparison of selected writing systems around the world. Attention will be paid to strategies used in various scripts for the transmission of spoken language to written form. Emphasis will be on scripts of the ancient world: their development, uses, and decipherment.

name: Paleoethnobotany
description: The study of ancient plants for food and other purposes through microbotanical remains and ethnobotanical research. Explores uses of microscopic markers such as phytogenic silica and starch granules to reconstruct human ecology, while using ethnobotanical information from traditional knowledge. The emphasis is on the Old World.
prereq: Archaeology 201 and 3 units of courses labelled Archaeology at the 400 level or above.

name: Archaeometry
description: Analytical methods for reconstructing various aspects of life in the past based on analysis and interpretation of the material record. The structures of materials at the microscopic and macroscopic levels; raw materials and production technologies; provenance; dating; prospection; dietry reconstruction; sampling and measurement. Archaeological case studies are used throughout.

name: Reconstructing Plains Culture
description: Archaeological plains cultures and the methodological and theoretical issues involved in the use of archaeological reconstructions of the past. Normally, focus will be on the Canadian Plains.
prereq: Archaeology 321 or consent of the Department.
antireq: Not open to students with credit in Archaeology 623.

name: Human Ecology
description: Current directions in various subfields of human ecology as they apply to Anthropology, Archaeology and Geography.
antireq: Not open to students with credit in Geography 523.

name: Spc Top:Underwater Arky
description: This course is offered periodically to meet special needs of students or visiting faculty members.

name: Adv Topics in Archaeology
description: Investigation of various theoretical, methodological, analytical, and/or topical issues in archaeology.

name: Adv Topics Analytical ARKY
description: Investigation of various methodological and/or analytical topics in archaeology at an advanced level.

name: TopicsMesoamericanArchaeology
description: Focus on particular time periods or themes in Mesoamerican archaeology and ethnohistory.

name: Caribbean Prehistory
description: The prehistory and history of the indigenous peoples of the Caribbean from the first peopling of the islands to the early contact period.
notes: Not open to students with credit in Archaeology 531.61.

name: Human Osteology
description: Identification and interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Emphasis is on functional anatomy and reconstruction of prehistoric lifeways.
antireq: Credit for Archaeology 555 and 613 will not be allowed.

rules.name: Credit for Archaeology 555 and 613 will not be allowed.

name: (Anth 589) Nutritional Anth
description: The study of human dietary practices from biological and cultural perspectives. Subjects covered include the development of nutritional anthropology, principles of nutrition, principles of ecology, diet from an evolutionary, comparative and historic perspective, the impact of undernutrition on human physiology, and behaviour and

name: Landscape Archaeology
description: Human perceptions and uses of the biophysical and cultural environment. The emphasis is on the act of humanizing the environment by naming places, identifying resources, establishing paths, and modifying the natural landscape thereby creating a tradition of land use that can be accessed archaeologically.

name: Household Archaeology
description: Human perceptions and uses of the built environment, particularly residential architecture. The emphasis is on

name: Prob in Palaeopath & Palaeonut
description: Patterns of disease in prehistoric human populations with consideration to the interaction of health and nutrition. Techniques for determining disease and nutrition from prehistoric remains are covered.
prereq: 9 units Anthropology 201, 350, Archaeology 555 and admission to the Archaeology or Anthropology major.

name: Independent Readings In Arky
description: An independent reading course for archaeology majors. Emphasis will be on the methodological, technical and scientific literature relating to archaeological interpretation. Each student is required to choose reading in consultation with an advisor.

name: Theoretical Foundations
description: The philosophy of science, the history of anthropological theory, and a survey of contemporary theoretical approaches in anthropology. Throughout, the relevance to and connections with the subdisciplines of archaeology and biological anthropology will be emphasized.

name: Seminar on Special Topics
description: Intensive study of special problems of particular interest to Archaeology Department graduate students. Subject matter for any particular year to be left to the discretion of the Department.

name: Advanced Zooarchaeology
description: Specialized techniques of zooarchaeological analysis employed in research areas including site seasonality, aging and sexing, paleo-environmental reconstruction and identification techniques for non-mammalian species.

name: Interpretation Lithic Analysis
description: Lithic analysis methodology, including issues such as reduction stage analysis, usewear and residue analysis, material sourcing, replication, and spatial patterning. The use of lithic remains in interpretation of the social behaviour of archaeological cultures.

description: Intensive study of selected archaeological problems.
